QAPair.Question: What is (are) Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia ?
QAPair.Answer: Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia is a condition that affects the movement of the eyes.

QAPair.Question: What causes Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia ?
QAPair.Answer: This disorder occurs because the brain is sending and receiving faulty information through the nerves that control eye movement. The nerves themselves are healthy. People who have this problem often have progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP). This is a disorder that affects the way the brain controls movement. Other disorders that have been associated with this condition include: Inflammation of the brain ( encephalitis ), Disease that causes areas deep in the brain, just above the spinal cord, to shrink ( olivopontocerebellar atrophy ), Disease of the nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord that control voluntary muscle movement ( amyotrophic lateral sclerosis ), Whipple disease (a condition that also causes malabsorption disorder of the small intestine as well as other symptoms) ,

QAPair.Question: What are the symptoms of Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia ?
QAPair.Answer: People with supranuclear ophthalmoplegia are unable to move their eyes at will in all directions, especially looking upward. Other symptoms may include: Mild dementia , Stiff and uncoordinated movements like those of Parkinson disease , Disorders associated with supranuclear ophthalmoplegia,

QAPair.Question: How to diagnose Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia ?
QAPair.Answer: The health care provider will perform a physical exam and ask about the symptoms, focusing on the eyes and nervous system. Tests will be done to check for diseases linked with supranuclear ophthalmoplegia. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) might show shrinking of the brainstem.

QAPair.Question: What are the treatments for Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia ?
QAPair.Answer: Treatment depends on the cause and symptoms of the supranuclear ophthalmoplegia.

QAPair.Question: What is the outlook for Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia ?
QAPair.Answer: Outlook depends on the cause of the supranuclear ophthalmoplegia.
